history.content:
CS 188 covers some reinforcement learning (currently a hot field in ML esp. at Berkeley), which is not covered in 126, 127, and 189 I believe. If you want to do any research that involves RL could be useful. Although it is a topic self studyable especially after you've taken 126, 127, and 189.

I took 188 after 189, concurrently with 126/127 (though I dropped 127) and thought it was still pretty interesting. Also necessary for a lot (read: pretty much all) of research and it's pretty easy so why not take it?

CS 188 covers some reinforcement learning (currently a hot field in ML esp. at Berkeley), which is not covered in 126, 127, and 189 I believe. If you want to do any research that involves RL could be useful. Although it is a topic self studyable especially after you've taken 126, 127, and 189.

CS 188 covers some reinforcement learning (currently a hot field in ML esp. at Berkeley), which is not covered in 126, 127, and 189 I believe. Although it is a topic self studyable especially after you've taken 126, 127, and 189.
CS 188 covers some reinforcement learning, which is not covered in 126, 127, and 189 I believe. Although it is a topic self studyable especially after you've taken 126, 127, and 189.

children.subject: If you want to do research in some area of AI, I suspect that most professors will at least require a strong performance in cs188

history.content:
I'll take 126, 127, and 189 within the next three semesters. I hope to eventually do research in some area of AI. Currently, I have zero awareness of what area I'd want that to be.  

Based on what I've seen, I understand 188 is a survey course that shallowly touches on concepts in several areas of AI. I have a few questions regarding this.

  • Is taking 188 an efficient and effective way of finding an area of AI I'd like to deeply pursue?
    • What are other better ways of helping with this purpose?
  • How much of 188 is not taught in 126/127/189? (What concepts in 188 are not taught in 126/127/189?)
  • What is the value in having the shallow breadth of AI knowledge taught in 188 given that I will eventually be deeply pursuing a specific area of AI? 
    • How generalizable are the concepts taught in 188?
  • How valuable is it to have taken 188 when trying to find a research opportunity in AI by contacting professors and graduate students?
    • By the end of next semester, I will have taken 126, 170, 70, 61A, 61B, Math 53, and Math 54. How much would also having taken 188 help with this purpose?

Any comments on my questions and other pros and cons of taking 188 would be appreciated! Thanks!
history.subject: What is the value of taking 188 if I'm already planning on taking 126, 127, and 189?
